facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 100 of 1969 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 100 of 1969.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 8, 1969 of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Application No. 1341 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 8, 1969 of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Application No. 1341 of 1968.

facts.text: Appellant and Bakshi Singh Sunder Singh were accused No. 2 and accused No. 1 respectively in commitment proceedings before the Presidency Magistrate, 28th Court, Greater Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and one Bakshi Singh Sunder Singh were accused No. 2 and accused No. 1 respectively in the commitment proceedings before the Presidency Magistrate, 28th Court, Greater Bombay.

facts.text: Bombay High Court refused to quash the order of commitment passed by the Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by special leave, is directed against the judgment of the High Court of Bombay refusing to quash the order of commitment passed by the learned Magistrate.

facts.text: On October 31, 1963, Jivansingh Uttam Singh obtained a British passport bearing No. 183459 at Nairobi.

anchor.surface_text: On October 31, 1963, one Jivansingh Uttam Singh obtained a British passport bearing No. 183459 at Nairobi.

facts.text: Jivansingh Uttam Singh was returning to India with his family and died on board the ship.

anchor.surface_text: On the strength of that passport he was returning to India with his family. On his way he died on board the ship.

facts.text: According to the prosecution, the passport came into the hands of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: According to the prosecution that passport came into the hands of the appellant.

facts.text: Bakshi Singh desired to go to the United Kingdom but had no passport.

anchor.surface_text: Bakshi Singh desired to go to the United Kingdom, but had no passport.

facts.text: The appellant agreed to arrange Bakshi Singh's journey and obtain a passport for him.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant agreed to arrange his journey and also for that purpose to obtain a passport for him.

facts.text: The appellant prepared an application for a visa in the name of Bakshi Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The allegation was that the appellant prepared an application for a visa in the name of Bakshi Singh.

facts.text: With a view to procure the visa, the photograph of deceased Jivansingh was removed from the passport and that of Bakshi Singh substituted.

anchor.surface_text: It was further alleged that with a view to procure the said visa the photograph of the said deceased Jivansingh was removed from the said passport and that of Bakshi Singh substituted.

facts.text: Visa was obtained and Bakshi Singh journeyed to the United Kingdom having made some intermediate halts.

anchor.surface_text: The visa having in this fashion been obtained, Bakshi Singh journeyed to the United Kingdom having on his way made some intermediate halts.

facts.text: British authorities suspected the passport was forged and repatriated Bakshi Singh to India.

anchor.surface_text: The British authorities suspected that the passport was a forged document and repatriated Bakshi Singh to India.

facts.text: Bakshi Singh was handed over to the Special Police, Bombay on arrival.

anchor.surface_text: On his arrival he was handed over to the Special Police, Bombay.

facts.text: Special Police carried out investigation and recorded statements including that of Tanna Singh, younger brother of Bakshi Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The Special Police carried out investigation in the course of which they recorded statements of certain witnesses including that of Tanna Singh, the younger brother of Bakshi Singh.

facts.text: Police filed a charge-sheet before the Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: On completion of the investigation, the police filed a charge-sheet before the learned Magistrate.

facts.text: Charge-sheet charged Bakshi Singh under sections 419 and 471 read with section 468, and appellant under sections 419/109, 468 and 471 of the Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: But counsel for the appellant informed us that Bakshi Singh was therein charged under secs. 419 and 471 read with sec. 468, and the appellant was charged under secs. 419/109, 468 and 471 of the Penal Code.

facts.text: Magistrate did not examine any witnesses during commitment proceedings but perused charge-sheet and documents under section 173 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel also informed us that the Magistrate did not examine any witnesses, during the commitment proceedings but on a perusal of the charge-sheet and the documents filed before him under sec. 173 of the Code of Criminal Procedure he framed the charges

facts.text: Magistrate committed Bakshi Singh and appellant for trial by order dated September 13, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: and committed, by his order dated September 13, 1968, Bakshi Singh and the appellant for trial before the Sessions Court.

facts.text: Magistrate framed charges: Bakshi Singh under secs. 120B, 419, 467 and 471 read with sec. 467; appellant under secs. 120B and 467 of the Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: By that order he directed the said Bakshi Singh to stand his trial under secs. 120B, 419, 467 and 471 read with sec. 467, and the appellant under secs. 120B and 467 of the Penal Code.

facts.text: Offence under sec. 120B was conspiracy to forge the passport for use of Bakshi Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The offence of criminal conspiracy charged under sec. 120B was that the said Bakshi Singh and the appellant had conspired to forge the said passport for the use of the said Bakshi Singh.

facts.text: In High Court, appellant raised contention that no consent under sec. 196A(2) obtained, so Magistrate had no jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court various contentions were raised on behalf of the appellant in support of his application under sec. 561A of the Code of Criminal Procedure including that under sec. 196A(2).

facts.text: Special leave granted limited to the ground of sec. 196A(2).

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal we are concerned only with that contention as the special leave granted to the appellant has been limited to that ground alone.

facts.text: Charge-sheet did not refer to or charge criminal conspiracy under sec. 120B.

anchor.surface_text: The charge-sheet admittedly did not refer to or charge either of them with criminal conspiracy under sec. 120B.

facts.text: None of the witnesses alleged criminal conspiracy by appellant with Bakshi Singh.

anchor.surface_text: it was conceded by counsel, after he himself had gone through them from the record, that none of the witnesses had alleged therein either directly or indirectly of the appellant having entered into a criminal conspiracy with Bakshi Singh for forging the passport.

issues.text: Whether the Magistrate had jurisdiction to take cognizance of the offence of criminal conspiracy under sec. 120B without prior consent under sec. 196A(2), rendering the committal order without jurisdiction?

anchor.surface_text: That contention was that no consent as required by sec. 196A 2 having been first obtained, the Magistrate had no jurisdiction to take cognizance of the offence of conspiracy, and therefore, the committal order was without jurisdiction and had to be quashed.

issues.text: Whether the Magistrate took cognizance of criminal conspiracy under sec. 120B upon receipt of the police charge-sheet under sec. 173 CrPC, or only of abetment under sec. 109 IPC?

anchor.surface_text: As has often been held taking cognizance does not involve any formal action or indeed action of any kind but occurs as soon as a Magistrate applies his mind to the suspected commission of an offence. Cognizance, therefore, takes place at a point when a magistrate first takes judicial notice of an offence.

issues.text: Whether the requirement of consent under sec. 196A(2) depends on the sections mentioned in the charge-sheet or on the offence prima facie and essentially disclosed by the facts alleged?

anchor.surface_text: The proper test should be whether the allegations made in the petition of complaint disclosed primarily and essentially an offence or offences for which a consent in writing would be necessary to the initiation of the proceedings within the meaning of s. 196A(2) of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

arguments.claim: No consent as required by sec. 196A(2) having been first obtained, the Magistrate had no jurisdiction to take cognizance of the offence of conspiracy under sec. 120B, and therefore the committal order was without jurisdiction and had to be quashed

anchor.surface_text: That contention was that no consent as required by sec. 196A 2  having been first obtained, the Magistrate had no jurisdiction to take cognizance of the offence of companyspiracy, and therefore, the companymittal order was without jurisdiction and had to be quashed.

arguments.court_reasoning: Magistrate took cognizance of abetment under sec. 109 upon police report, not of conspiracy under sec. 120B; consent required only for conspiracy where object is non-cognizable offence

arguments.claim: Taking cognizance occurs as soon as a Magistrate applies his mind to the suspected commission of an offence, and upon a police report, prima facie of the offence or offences disclosed in such report

anchor.surface_text: As has often been held taking companynizance does number involve any formal action or indeed action of any kind but occurs as soon as a Magistrate applies his mind to the suspected companymission of an offence. Cognizance, therefore, takes place at a point when a magistrate first takes judicial numberice of an offence.

arguments.claim: The charge-sheet did not refer to or charge either accused with criminal conspiracy under sec. 120B; it charged offences under secs. 419/109, 468 and 471

anchor.surface_text: It is number in dispute that the charge-sheet submitted by the police officer for the purpose of initiation of proceedings by the magistrate was for offences under sees. 419 and 471 read with sec. 468 against Bakshi Singh and under sees. 419/109, 471 and 468 against the appellant. The charge- sheet admittedly did number refer to or charge either of them with criminal companyspiracy under sec. 120B.

arguments.claim: Prima facie the Magistrate took cognizance of the offences alleged in the charge-sheet (abetment etc.), not under sec. 120B, as that was not alleged

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie it is number possible to say that at the stage when the police filed the charge-sheet the Magistrate took companynizance of the offence, under sec. 120B, for, that was number the offence alleg ed in the charge-sheet to have been companymitted by either of the two accused persons.

arguments.claim: The Magistrate framed charges under sec. 120B at a later stage (framing charges and committal), but cognizance was taken earlier upon the police report of abetment offences

anchor.surface_text: True it is that the Magistrate ultimately drew up charges which included the offence under sec. 120B... It was at a later stage, i.e., at the time of passing the companymittal order that he companysidered that a charge under sec. 120B was the more appropriate charge and number a charge under sec. 109 of the Penal Code.

arguments.claim: The proper test for whether consent under sec. 196A(2) is required is whether the allegations disclose primarily and essentially an offence requiring consent, not merely sections named or allusions to conspiracy

anchor.surface_text: The proper test should be whether the allegations made in the petition of companyplaint disclosed primarily and essentially an offence or offences for which a companysent in writing would be necessary to the initiation of the proceedings within the meaning of s. 196A(2) of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

arguments.court_reasoning: Applied from Pramatha Nath Taluqdar v. Saroj Ranjan Sarkar

arguments.claim: Whether sanction is necessary depends not on the sections referred to but on the offence prima facie disclosed by the facts alleged

anchor.surface_text: Counsel in this companynection relied on certain observations made in a minority judgment of S. K. Das, J., in Pramatha Nath Taluqdar v. Saroj Ranjan Sarkar.

arguments.court_reasoning: Observations support the prima facie test applied by court, holding abetment primary offence

holdings.text: taking cognizance does not involve any formal action or indeed action of any kind but occurs as soon as a Magistrate applies his mind to the suspected commission of an offence. Cognizance, therefore, takes place at a point when a magistrate first takes judicial notice of an offence.

anchor.surface_text: As has often been held taking cognizance does not involve any formal action or indeed action of any kind but occurs as soon as a Magistrate applies his mind to the suspected commission of an offence. Cognizance, therefore, takes place at a point when a magistrate first takes judicial notice of an offence. This is the position whether the magistrate takes cognizance of an offence on a complaint or on a police report, or upon information of a person other than a police officer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restatement of established position from precedents on when cognizance occurs, applied to police report context.

holdings.text: when a magistrate takes cognizance of an offence upon a police report, prima facie he does so of the offence or offences disclosed in such report.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, when a magistrate takes cognizance of an offence upon a police report, prima facie he does so of the offence or offences disclosed in such report. It is not in dispute that the charge-sheet submitted by the police officer for the purpose of initiation of proceedings by the magistrate was for offences under secs. 419 and 471 read with sec. 468 against Bakshi Singh and under secs. 419/109, 471 and 468 against the appellant. The charge-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cognizance on police report limited prima facie to offences alleged therein; charge-sheet lacked s.120B.

holdings.text: Prima facie it is not possible to say that at the stage when the police filed the charge-sheet the Magistrate took cognizance of the offence, under sec. 120B, for, that was not the offence alleged in the charge-sheet to have been committed by either of the two accused persons.

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie it is not possible to say that at the stage when the police filed the charge-sheet the Magistrate took cognizance of the offence, under sec. 120B, for, that was not the offence alleged in the charge-sheet to have been committed by either of the two accused persons. True it is that the Magistrate ultimately drew up charges which included the offence under sec. 120B, the object of which was to forge the passport, an offence under sec. 467.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No allegation of s.120B in charge-sheet or witness statements; cognizance stage precedes framing charges.

holdings.text: That being so, it must be held that the Magistrate took cognizance of the offence of abetment of an offence of forgery and impersonation so far as the appellant was concerned and not of the offence of criminal conspiracy, and therefore, sec. 196A 2 did not apply.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction between initial cognizance of abetment offences in charge-sheet and later framing of conspiracy charge; s.196A(2) inapplicable to abetment.

holdings.text: The proper test should be whether the allegations made in the petition of complaint disclosed primarily and essentially an offence or offences for which a consent in writing would be necessary to the initiation of the proceedings within the meaning of s. 196A(2) of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: The proper test should be whether the allegations made in the petition of complaint disclosed primarily and essentially an offence or offences for which a consent in writing would be necessary to the initiation of the proceedings within the meaning of s. 196A(2) of the Code of Criminal Procedure. It is from that point of view that the petition of complaint must be examined. The learned Judge ultimately held that though the offence of criminal conspiracy was alluded to in para 5 of thesaid complaint, the offence primarily and essentially chargedwas abetment by conspiracy under sec. 109 of the Penal Code,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopted from Pramatha Nath (minority observation approved); sanction depends on primary offence in facts, not labels.

holdings.text: the offence primarily and essentially alleged therein was one of abetment of forgery under secs. 468 and 471 and of false impersonation under sec. 419 read with sec. 109.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of primary offence test to charge-sheet and witness statements; no conspiracy alleged.

holdings.text: it is impossible to sustain the argument that the Magistrate took cognizance of the offence under sec. 120B, and therefore, consent under sec. 196A 2 was required as a condition precedent or that the committal order and the proceedings for committal which he took were vitiated for want of such consent. The appeal, therefore, fails and is dismissed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative: no prima facie conspiracy in materials; proceedings valid; appeal dismissed.

precedents.citation: Pramatha Nath Taluqdar v. Saroj Ranjan Sarkar.  1 [1962 Supp. 2 S.C.R. 297]

anchor.surface_text: Pramatha Nath Taluqdar v. Saroj Ranjan Sarkar.  1  The question involved there was, whether a second companyplaint companyld be entertained by a magistrate who or whose predecessor had on the same or similar allegations dismissed a previous companyplaint, and if so, in what circumstances should such a companyplaint be entertained. Arising-. out of this question a companytention was raised whether on the companyplaint, as it was framed, the Magistrate had the jurisdiction to, take companynizance of the offences alleged in the companyplaint in the absence of a sanction under sec. 196A.

precedents.case_name: Pramatha Nath Taluqdar v Saroj Ranjan Sarkar
precedents.cited_proposition: The proper test for whether sanction under s. 196A(2) is required is whether the allegations in the complaint disclose primarily and essentially an offence for which consent is necessary, not merely the sections mentioned or use of the expression 'criminal conspiracy'.
precedents.cited_holding: though the offence of criminal companyspiracy was alluded to in para 5 of the companyplaint, the offence primarily and essentially charged was abetment by companyspiracy under sec. 109 of the Penal Code, and therefore no consent under sec. 196A(2) was required.

anchor.surface_text: In Biroo Sardar v. Ariff  2  the view also taken was that itis number the, sections referred to which matter but the offence prima facie disclosed. Following that decision, the High Court of Bombay in Ramchandra v. Emperor 3  observed that the question whether sanction is necessary or number depends number on the sections referred to in a companyplaint but the offence prima facie disclosed. by the facts alleged in it.

precedents.cited_proposition: Sanction is determined by the offence prima facie disclosed by the facts, not the sections referred to.

anchor.surface_text: Following that decision, the High Court of Bombay in Ramchandra v. Emperor 3  observed that the question whether sanction is necessary or number depends number on the sections referred to in a companyplaint but the offence prima facie disclosed. by the facts alleged in it. It is clear from the charge-sheet submitted to the magistrate that the offence of criminal companyspiracy was number even referred to.

precedents.cited_proposition: The question whether sanction is necessary depends not on the sections referred to in a complaint but on the offence prima facie disclosed by the facts alleged in it.

edges.explanation: Holding defines taking cognizance as Magistrate applying mind to suspected offence, directly addressing the issue of whether cognizance was taken of sec. 120B or only sec. 109 upon police charge-sheet.

anchor.surface_text: As has often been held taking cognizance does not involve any formal action or indeed action of any kind but occurs as soon as a Magistrate applies his mind to the suspected commission of an offence. Cognizance, therefore, takes place at a point when a magistrate first takes judicial notice of an offence. This is the position whether the magistrate takes cognizance of an offence on a complaint or on a police report, or upon information of a person other than a police officer.
The appeal, therefore, fails and is dismissed.

edges.explanation: Holding states that upon police report, cognizance is prima facie of offences disclosed in the report, directly addressing the issue concerning cognizance of specific offences in charge-sheet.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, when a magistrate takes cognizance of an offence upon a police report, prima facie he does so of the offence or offences disclosed in such report. It is not in dispute that the charge-sheet submitted by the police officer for the purpose of initiation of proceedings by the magistrate was for offences under secs. 419 and 471 read with sec. 468 against Bakshi Singh and under secs. 419/109, 471 and 468 against the appellant. The charge-

edges.explanation: Holding concludes prima facie no cognizance of sec. 120B at charge-sheet stage as it was not the offence charged, directly addressing and resolving the issue.

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie it is not possible to say that at the stage when the police filed the charge-sheet the Magistrate took cognizance of the offence, under sec. 120B, for, that was not the offence alleged in the charge-sheet to have been committed by either of the two accused persons. True it is that the Magistrate ultimately drew up charges which included the offence under sec. 120B, the object of which was to forge the passport, an offence under sec. 467.
The appeal, therefore, fails and is dismissed.

edges.explanation: Holding h5 states the proper test based on allegations in the complaint disclosing primarily and essentially an offence requiring consent, directly addressing the issue i3 on whether consent depends on charge-sheet sections or prima facie facts alleged.

anchor.surface_text: The proper test should be whether the allegations made in the petition of complaint disclosed primarily and essentially an offence or offences for which a consent in writing would be necessary to the initiation of the proceedings within the meaning of s. 196A(2) of the Code of Criminal Procedure. It is from that point of view that the petition of complaint must be examined. The learned Judge ultimately held that though the offence of criminal conspiracy was alluded to in para 5 of thesaid complaint, the offence primarily and essentially chargedwas abetment by conspiracy under sec. 109 of the Penal Code,
The appeal, therefore, fails and is dismissed.
